Home Safety Tips

HomeHero™ is concerned for you and your family's home fire safety. Our commitment is to provide you insight into preventative home safety measures that you and your loved ones can learn about and practice as a part of your normal daily routines. We have identified some of the best fire safety and prevention information available online from government and educational organizations. This information is organized into two specific categories:

  • Prevention First
  • Responsive Action

Fact: The majority of deaths and injuries from fire occur in the home. >>

While America's buildings are built to high standards and our fire departments are among the best in the world, the United States and Canada have the highest death rates from fire of any industrialized nation. Fire safety experts tell us those most likely to die are often children under 5 years of age, and adults over 65. The problem is due in part to our lack of fire safety awareness and preparedness and its importance in our everyday lives.

Tips:

Fire Safety Checklist
Reduce the risks that cause fire. Create a fire safety checklist that involves the whole family.
Prevention By Topic
Eliminate the silent fire hazards in your home. Learn how your family can be better protected.
Seasonal Fire Prevention
Every season brings unique fire hazards. Learn what you can do to prevent them.
Select a Group
  • Basics for everyone
  • New Parents & Families
  • College Students
  • Teachers
  • Kids
  • Seniors
  • Disabled Persons
  • Apartment/Mobile Home

HomeHero™ has selected special governmental and educational websites offering information for your whole family on how to prevent fires. Find out what fire safety experts are saying about fire awareness, fire prevention, and detection of deadly fumes like carbon monoxide. We hope you will take advantage of the important information made available to you through the HomeHero website. Make a fire safety plan and practice it regularly because safety at hand can provide you and your loved ones a greater peace of mind.

  • Learn what fire safety experts know about the dangers of fire.
  • Practice prevention but prepare for the worst. Plan now to escape.

Learn Safety:

Educate and mentor children about the importance of fire safety and prevention.

Safety Checklist:

Discover just how safe your home currently is with a fire safety checklist.

Candle Fires:

Improper use of candles are dangerous. Learn how to use them safely year round.

Protect Your Family:

Educate your entire family on the importance of fire safety awareness and prevention.

Know The Drill:

Create a fire escape plan and fire safety checklist to keep your family prepared.

Safety Awareness

Keep the whole family involved in fire safety awareness and prevention by having a UL registered fire extinguisher close at hand. More >>

Cooking fires are some of the most common fires in a home. Do you know what to look for in your kitchen to prevent a fire? More >>

From October 7-13, fire safety advocates across the country will be spreading the word that when it comes to escape plans, practice is key. Whether you're a firefighter, a teacher or a parent, we've got lots of helpful information. So let's get started! More >>
